keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed and snapped, leading to a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable did not meet the specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular’s operator, and failed certification standards.
Maintenance tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as 'compliant and accepted'.
Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic and out of control, with one man named Bruno recalling the car appearing like a toy and hearing screams and a loud bang.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and brakes in its interim report.
The interim findings are preliminary and not conclusive; a final report is expected to be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped during operation. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet CARRIS’s operational specifications and that maintenance records were falsified, with tasks marked as completed despite non-compliance. Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic, with one man named Bruno recounting the car's violent motion and the sudden appearance of smoke and screams. While the interim report identifies serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance, and braking systems, authorities stress that the findings are preliminary and a final report will be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
